title: CBC Radio
text:
On Thursday, Russian authorities staged nationwide raids said to target the country's opposition figures. These raids come the same week that Russia's ruling party was dealt a blow in Moscow's local elections, losing as many as one-third of the seats in the country's municipal parliament.

For many, these losses are product of a broader effort for change in Russia — as the country has seen its most inspired anti-government protests in years, and President Vladimir Putin's approval numbers reach all-time lows.

Today on Front Burner, we talk to the CBC's Moscow correspondent Chris Brown about the future of Russia's strongman president, and how he maintains control.
description: Today on Front Burner, CBC’s Moscow Correspondent Chris Brown takes us through Vladimir Putin’s decades-long grip on power, and whether or not a popular protest movement and falling approval numbers could signal change for Russia's political future.
